name: Avoid calling blocking functions with an infinite timeout
description:
This rule searches for C++ methods that call blocking functions with the infinite timeout parameter. Functions that are detected by the rule are:
- WaitForSingleObject() 
- WaitForMultipleObjects() 
- Sleep()
output:
Associated to each C++ method with violations, the Quality Rule provides:
- the number of violation occurrences
- Bookmarks for violation occurrences found in source code:
  - blocking function call
rationale:
Calling this type of function with parameters corresponding to infinite timeout can lead to program blocking and/or deadlock. 

Even if the logical behavior would be to wait infinitely until some event occurs, it can be good practice to add a timeout to detect a bad situation (such as a probable deadlock).
remediation: Correct this violation by adding logic that deals with a situation when the mutex is never released.
alternativeName: Avoid calling blocking functions with an infinite timeout

technicalCriteria.name: CWE-1088: Synchronous Access of Remote Resource without Timeout

qualityStandards.name: Synchronous Call Time-Out Absence
qualityStandards.description:
Objective
Avoid synchronous remote resource access without handling time-out capabilities

Consequence
Software featuring blocking calls to remote systems incurs the risk of own failure when the remote systems fails to process the call correctly.

Measure Element
Number of instances where a synchronous call instruction is initiated but the time-out argument is not set or is set to infinite time

qualityStandards.name: Incorrect Synchronization
qualityStandards.description: The software utilizes a shared resource in a concurrent manner, but it does not correctly synchronize access to the resource.

qualityStandards.name: Synchronous Access of Remote Resource without Timeout
qualityStandards.description: The code has a synchronous call to a remote resource, but there is no timeout for the call, or the timeout is set to infinite.
